channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: French Leader Brushes Aside Questions Over Affair
item.description: Invoking his right to privacy, François Hollande said that everyone suffers “difficult moments” but that the annual presidential news conference was not the place to discuss them.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN
item.media:description: President François Hollande of France brushed aside questions about his personal life on Tuesday.

item.title: N.S.A. Devises Radio Pathway Into Computers
item.description: The agency has used a covert channel of radio waves to reach computers that adversaries have tried to make impervious to spying or cyberattack.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and THOM SHANKER
item.media:description: The headquarters of the National Security Agency at Fort Meade, Md. “We do not use foreign intelligence capabilities to steal the trade secrets of foreign companies,” an N.S.A. official said.

item.title: The Lede: Republican Ideas on Immigration Could Legalize Up to 6.5 Million, Study Says
item.description: “Half a loaf” proposals may put many more on a so-called path to citizenship than immigrant advocates have previously thought.
item.dc:creator: By JULIA PRESTON
item.media:description: A Dream Action Coalition demonstration last month.

item.title: Judge Warns Proposed Safeguards Could Hamper Surveillance Court
item.description: A federal judge advised President Obama and Congress not to let a public advocate “intervene at will” in opposing Justice Department briefs.
item.category: Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Documents Spur British Inquiry Over 1984 Raid At Indian Shrine
item.description: Documents released after 30 years suggest that British special forces had helped draw up plans for the attack at the Golden Temple at Amritsar, India.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: India Ink: A Feverish Welcome for Indian Diplomat in Hometown of Mumbai
item.description: Several dozen supporters greeted the Indian diplomat Devyani Khobragade in Mumbai, in a gathering that was as much a show of support for Ms. Khobragade, who was indicted in the United States on charges of visa fraud, as it was a protest against Americans.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Devyani Khobragade, an Indian diplomat, was surrounded by supporters at a Mumbai airport on Tuesday.

item.title: Tunisian Constitution, Praised for Balance, Nears Passage
item.description: Legislators across the political spectrum and human rights groups hailed the charter, considered one of the most liberal in an Arab nation, as a triumph of consensus politics.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:description: Tunisians wave the national flag at a rally in Tunis marking the third anniversary of the country's revolution.

item.title: Thai Leader Vows to Keep Job Amid Protests
item.description: Antigovernment demonstrators marched Tuesday to government offices as part of a so-called shutdown of the Thai capital.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters stood outside the Thai Customs Department building in Bangkok on Tuesday.

item.title: DealBook: Japan’s Suntory Buys Jim Beam for $13.6 Billion
item.description: The move means such longtime American brands as Jim Beam and Maker’s Mark bourbons will be owned by a Japanese giant.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED and DAVID GELLES
item.media:credit: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg News, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A bottling line of Jim Beam Maple bourbon in Clermont, Ky. The deal was for $13.6 billion, a rich premium.

item.title: Israeli Minister’s Reported Comments Deriding Peace Effort Draw U.S. Rebuke
item.description: A news report that the Israeli defense minister thinks John Kerry’s efforts are naïve and messianic drew criticism from Washington, and some Israeli leaders.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Scores Die in Ferry Accident as They Flee Violence in South Sudan
item.description: Reports said a ferry accident claimed the lives of more than 200 people who were trying to escape a rebel advance on Malakal, the capital of the oil-rich state of Upper Nile.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Central African Republic Violence Ebbs, but U.N. Warns of Flare-Up
item.description: The United Nations human rights office released a report implicating Chadian members of the African peacekeeping mission in attacks on civilians.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Euro Zone Factory Output Rallied in November
item.description: Industrial production rose by 1.8 percent compared with the previous month, ending a two-month decline, official data showed.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY

item.title: As Parents Age, Asian-Americans Struggle to Obey A Cultural Code
item.description: Asian-Americans are struggling to abide by a strong tradition in which they are commonly expected to care for their parents at home, but few institutions are prepared to help.
item.dc:creator: By TANZINA VEGA
item.media:credit: Jessica Kourkounis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Phuong Lu, right, quit her job at a nail salon two years ago to stay home and care for her mother, Doanh Nguyen, 81, when her symptoms of Alzheimer's worsened.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: January 14
item.description: The head priest of Hazratbal shrine in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, displaying a relic of the Prophet Muhammad.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: The head priest of Hazratbal shrine in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, displaying a relic of the Prophet Muhammad on the occasion of Eid-e-Milad-un-Nabi, which celebrates the birth of the prophet.

item.title: Red Tape Snarls Projects in India
item.description: The Mumbai Trans Harbor Link is one of numerous projects in India sorely needed to create economic growth but delayed because of government bureaucracy.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Building a train station in Chennai, India. Numerous projects that are sorely needed to create growth in the country have been delayed.

item.title: Egyptians Vote on New Constitution in Referendum
item.description: Residents on Tuesday began two days of voting on a charter that the country’s top military officer has cast as a potential precursor to a bid for the presidency.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Egyptian received a ballot for the constitutional referendum at a polling station in Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Electrical Problem Blamed in Shangri-La Fire
item.description: The blaze in the Chinese province of Yunnan, in an area said to be the inspiration for the novel “Lost Horizon,” badly damaged or destroyed 343 structures and left about 2,600 people homeless, the local government said.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: The fire left most of Dukezong's old center in ruins.

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: At Globalfest, Music Speaks Many Languages
item.description: Globalfest 2014 was a 12-act world-music showcase that included dance music, gospel, African beats and many other genres.
item.media:credit: Brian Harkin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fanfare Ciocarlia, a Romanian brass band, epitomized the variety onstage Sunday at Globalfest.

item.title: Obama Fights a Push to Add Iran Sanctions
item.description: With the United States and Iran set to embark on a critical phase of nuclear talks, President Obama is struggling to prevent Senate Democrats from backing a bill that could thwart his diplomatic efforts.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JONATHAN WEISMAN
item.media:description: President Obama fears that new sanctions could upend nuclear negotiations. But senators from both parties say the West needs the specter of more sanctions as a “diplomatic insurance policy.”

item.title: India Ink: Tiger Attacks Terrify Villagers Near Southern Hill Station
item.description: Near Ooty, a popular tourist destination in Tamil Nadu, lives have been put on hold while hundreds of forest and police officers look for a tiger that has killed three people since Jan. 4.
item.dc:creator: By RAKSHA KUMAR

item.title: Letter From Europe: Jack Monroe Has Become Britain’s Austerity Celebrity
item.description: A single mother’s story of her slide into poverty and hunger has resonated in austerity-era Britain.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Monroe in her home in Southend, England.

item.title: India Ink: The Skate Escape
item.description: In Bangalore, skateboarding has become an unlikely refuge for stressed-out young professionals and street kids.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM B. LERNER
item.media:description: Abhishek, who goes by one name, skating at the Play Arena Skatepark in Bangalore, Karnataka, on Dec. 22, 2013.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: A Dark Look at Modeling in China
item.description: An American writer details what it was like working for several months as a model in China, a job she describes as “the dregs of the modeling world, the bottom rung of the high­ fashion ladder.”
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Models present creations by the Chinese fashion label OudiFu during China Fashion Week in Beijing, March 2012.

item.title: U.S. Presses Syrian Opposition to Join Talks
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry told the rebel coalition that support could be reduced if it does not attend the upcoming peace conference in Switzerland.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON
